title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
1. Motivating example


Research question: “To what extent do different teaching methods influence students’ ability to produce high-quality written texts?”
Method: Randomization and a CJ experiment, specifically:




Assign students to two different teaching method
Students will write preferably more than one text
We will collect these texts
We will assign judges to compare random pairs of texts
Judges will produce a dichotomous outcome, reflecting the relative quality of each text




Estimand: “On average, is there a difference in the ability to produce high-quality written texts between the two groups of students?”
Estimator: the BTL model
Estimates: BTL scores, or their transformations



Following current CJ practices

3. Some issues with this practice
What are the issues with this practice?:



Excessive reliance on Case V’s assumptions for the analysis of CJ data
\(\longrightarrow\) the assumption of equal dispersion between stimuli
\(\longrightarrow\) the assumption of zero correlation between stimuli
Disconnect between trait measurement and hypothesis testing

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
section: Issue 1: Case V and statistical analysis
text:
Issue 1: Case V and statistical analysis
So, are Case V assumptions violated?


Thurstone: equal dispersion may not be applicable when researchers assess complex traits or heterogeneous stimuli, like texts!
\(\longrightarrow\) Evidence of this can be found in misfit statistics?
Zero correlation is almost certainly invalid in two scenarios:
\(\longrightarrow\) when intricate aspects of texts generate judges’ biases, ultimately introducing dependencies between texts.
\(\longrightarrow\) when an additional hierarchical structure is relevant to the texts.



Equal dispersion:

“misfits” texts are texts with more judgment discrepancies than others [1–4]
“misfit” judges are judges who deviate substantially from the shared consensus.

Zero correlation:

additional relevant characteristics, exert an uneven influence on judges’ perceptions, creating biases. Since the discriminal difference of the stimuli becomes an observable outcome only through the judges’ perceptions, these biases introduce dependencies between the stimuli.
the shared context created by additional hierarchical structures introduce dependencies between stimuli (clustering) Not properly handled

Issue 1: Case V and statistical analysis
But, what problems result from the violations of assumptions?













Figure 2: The effect of dispersion discrepancies and stimuli correlation on the distribution of the discriminal difference. Left panel illustrates the effect of dispersion discrepancies. Right panel depicts the effect of stimuli correlation.




The outcome’s ability to reflect the “true” differences between texts largely depends on the validity of the model’s assumptions [5].



Different dispersions, neglecting judges’ biases and hierarchical structures
\(\longrightarrow\) reduce precision of parameter estimates
\(\longrightarrow\) overestimation of trait’s reliability
\(\longrightarrow\) drawing spurious conclusions [6]
Conventional practice of discarding ‘misfit’ observations [1–4]
\(\longrightarrow\) discard valuable information
\(\longrightarrow\) introduce bias into trait estimates [6, 7]
\(\longrightarrow\) drawing spurious conclusions [6]

text:
Issue 2: Measurement and hypothesis tests
Researchers use the BTL model as a measurement model for CJ [2–4, 8–12], i.e., they use the estimated BTL scores, or their transformations, to conduct additional analyses or hypothesis tests, for example:



Identify ‘misfit’ judges and stimuli [2–4]
Detect biases in judges’ ratings [2, 13]
Calculate correlations with other assessment methods [4, 12],
Test hypotheses related to the underlying trait of interest [12, 14–19]

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
Issue 2: Measurement and hypothesis tests
So, what are the problems with this?
















Figure 3: The effect of measurement error on the estimation of a regression parameter \(\beta\). Measurement error increases from left to right.





Ignoring uncertainty of BTL scores
\(\longrightarrow\) introduce bias + reduce the precision of hypothesis tests [20, 21]
\(\longrightarrow\) diminish statistical power of tests
\(\longrightarrow\) increase likelihood of type-I or type-II errors [6], i.e., drawing spurious conclusions.


We need a more systematic and integrated framework that enhances statistical accuracy while strengthening measurement reliability and validity.

\[
\begin{aligned}
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & := f_{O}(D_{RPUV}) \\

  B_{JK} & := f_{B}(B_{J}, Z_{JK}, e_{JK}) \\
  B_{J} & := f_{B}(Z_{J}, e_{J}) \\
  e_{IA} & \:\bot\:\{ e_{I}, e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{I} & \:\bot\:\{ e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{JK} & \:\bot\:e_{J}
\end{aligned}
\]

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
5. Abandoning the BTL model
With Bayesian inference we convert the SCM into a statistical model






\[
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & := f_{C}(O^{sc}_{RPUV}, C) \\
  O^{sc}_{RPUV} & := f_{S}(O^{cp}_{RPUV}, S_{RPUV}) \\
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & := f_{O}(D_{RPUV}) \\
  D_{RPUV} & := f_{D}(T_{IA}, B_{JK}) \\
  T_{IA} & := f_{T}(T_{I}, X_{A}, e_{IA}) \\
  T_{I} & := f_{T}(X_{I}, e_{I}) \\
  B_{JK} & := f_{B}(B_{J}, Z_{K}, e_{JK}) \\
  B_{J} & := f_{B}(Z_{J}, e_{J}) \\
  e_{IA} & \:\bot\:\{ e_{I}, e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{I} & \:\bot\:\{ e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{JK} & \:\bot\:e_{J}
\end{aligned}
\]


\[
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & = O^{sc}_{RPUV} \odot C \\
  O^{sc}_{RPUV} & = O^{cp}_{RPUV} \odot S_{RPUV} \\
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & \sim \text{Bernoulli} \left[ \text{inv_logit}( D_{RPUV} ) \right] \\
  D_{RPUV} & = \left( T_{IA}[R_{1},P_{1}] - T_{IA}[R_{2},P_{2}] \right) + B_{JK}[U,V] \\
  T_{IA} & = T_{I} + \beta_{XA} X_{IA} + e_{IA} \\
  T_{I} & = \beta_{XI} X_{I} + e_{I} \\
  B_{JK} & = B_{J} + \beta_{ZK} Z_{JK} + e_{JK} \\
  B_{J} & = \beta_{ZJ} Z_{J} + e_{J} \\
  e_{IA} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{IA}) \\  
  e_{I} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, \color{red}{s^{g}_{I}} ) \color{red}{\longleftarrow} \\
  e_{JK} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{JK}) \\
  e_{J} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, \color{red}{s^{g}_{J}} ) \color{red}{\longleftarrow} \\
  \\
  & \text{contraints:} \\
  & \sum_{g=1}^{G_{I}} s^{g}_{I}/G_{I} = 1 ; \quad \sum_{g=1}^{G_{J}} s^{g}_{J}/G_{J} = 1
\end{aligned}
\]




Figure 6: Sample-comparison model including sample and comparison mechanisms. Left panel illustrates the sample-comparison SCM. Right panel depicts the statistical model.

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.1 Discussion: Findings
We have proposed a model that:


Shifts the analysis paradigm from passively accepting to actively testing whether the assumptions fit the data [26]. Specifically, we have lifted the necessity of assuming:




Zero correlation between texts
Separate process for trait measurement and hypothesis testing
Equal dispersions between students or texts
No judgment biases (new)
Dichotomous outcome (new)
Need for removal of ‘misfit’ observations (new)
Normal \(e_{IA}, e_{I}, e_{JK},e_{J}\) idiosyncrasies (new)\(^{1}\)
Only two hierarchical components (new)\(^{1}\)
Multidimensional traits (new)\(^{1}\)






Stretching a bit the possibilities. Requires simulation analysis.

We have proposed a model that:

Students and texts
Judges and judgments (new)

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.2 Discussion: Limitations


Tested only in simulation scenarios (context dependent)
Researcher need a deep knowledge of Causal inference
\(\longrightarrow\) e.g., what does it mean for predictor variables \(X_{IA}, X_{I}, Z_{JK}, Z_{J}\) to be part of the sufficient adjustment set.
Researcher need knowledge of Probabilistic Programming Languages (PPL)
Researcher need knowledge of Bayesian inference methods



a sufficient adjustment set of variables (potentially an empty set) refers to those that satisfy the backdoor criterion [25], that is, variables that block all non-causal paths without introducing new ones [22, 23, 27].
Naturally, the validity of causal claims now hinges on the assumption that these variables serve as a sufficient adjustment set, a property that cannot be guaranteed for any variable. Nevertheless, as [5] noted, drawing conclusions about the real world from observed data inevitably requires assumptions, and these requirements hold true for both observational and experimental data.

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
6.2 Discussion: Further research


Model testing trough simulation and power analysis (context dependent)
Apply the model to, for instance, replication studies:




“New” rules of thumb for sample sizes
“New” rules of thumb for number of comparisons
Are there benefits of adaptive comparative algorithms?
Effects of predictor variables on students, texts, judges, and judgments
Do repeated judgments bring benefits?
Are additive better than multiplicative judges’ biases (akin to discrimination parameter in IRT)
How to work with random and non-random samples
etc. etc. etc.
